headline: As Domestic Violence Surges, City Funding To Fight Crisis Set To Drop Dramatically
author:
by
				Mina Bloom
article_text: CITY HALL â€” After enduring psychological abuse at the hands of her partner, Margarita Trujillo decided several years ago to â€œchange [her] own situationâ€ and seek counseling from a local community organization, she said. But the Little Village mother was denied services because the organization only provided counseling to survivors of physical abuse. â€œIt deeply saddened me because, psychologically, I felt not well. It did not seem fair. I wish I had the emotional support I needed,â€ Trujillo said in Spanish while addressing a City Council committee Wednesday. Now a survivor leader with the organization Healing to Action, Trujillo is among a growing number of advocates demanding more city funding to fight high levels of domestic violence, an alarming trend that has worsened since the COVD-19 pandemic lockdowns. RELATED: As Chicagoâ€™s Domestic Violence Crisis Deepens, Victims Suffer In Silence During the hearing convened by the councilâ€™s Committee on Health and Human Services, advocates representing a range of local organizations pushed alderpeople to support a significant increase in resources for gender-based violence services. Mayor Brandon Johnson is expected to release his 2026 budget recommendations next month, which will kick off weeks of discussions and negotiations with City Council members. Overall violence in the city has decreased significantly in recent years, according to Chicago police figures. Yet domestic violence remains higher than pre-pandemic levels, Ald. Daniel La Spata (1st) noted at the hearing. As of Wednesday, domestic homicides were up 18 percent over last year, according to the cityâ€™s violence reduction dashboard. Fatal domestic shootings have increased by 46 percent over the same time period. Calls to the Illinois domestic violence hotline have more than doubled since before the pandemic. Yet city funding for gender-based violence services is set to drop dramatically. This year, the city budgeted $21 million for gender-based violence services, which include community-based programs that offer legal aid, counseling and advocacy, and rapid rehousing. That investment is expected to shrink by half as COVID-era federal funding runs out and as funds from a tax on short-term housing rentals are depleted, according to figures provided by the city. A Block Club investigation earlier this year highlighted the funding shortfalls. It also recounted the story of DeMarieâ€™ Williams, who was killed, allegedly by her boyfriend, after months of abuse, according to prosecutors and her family and friends. The city reductions would also come after deep cuts to the federal Victims of Crime Act (VOCA) program. VOCA is supported by fines and penalties collected through federal criminal cases. Because the number of federal prosecutions has dropped and the Justice Department is reaching more settlements, VOCA funding fell by 40 percent in 2024. Though the state recently increased funding for gender-based violence services, it hasnâ€™t been enough to close the deficit created by VOCA cuts, organization leaders have said. Resilience, a crisis center that provides services to rape and sexual assault survivors, lost half a million dollars from VOCA cuts, said organization leader Sarah Layden. That meant the organization had to terminate six full-time positions, a mix of advocates and trauma therapists, she said. Gender-based violence organizations across the city are now scrambling again as pandemic subsides dry up. â€œWith the end of [American Rescue Plan Act] funding, weâ€™re now expected to serve more survivors with more complex needs with less money,â€ Layden said. Immigrant survivors in particular need more resources in light of President Donald Trumpâ€™s immigration enforcement efforts across the city, said Sayeed Sanchez, advocacy and policy manager for Mujeres LatinasÂ en AcciÃ³n, a bilingual organization focused on serving Latina survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault. Earlier this month, Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents took two people into custody at Cook Countyâ€™s domestic violence court. â€œAs survivors are being targeted more and more over their immigration status, Chicago has a powerful opportunity to reaffirm its commitment to meeting all of the needs of all Chicagoans, inclusive of immigrant survivors,â€ Sanchez said at the committee hearing. The cityâ€™s overall financial outlook is gloomy. Chicago is facing a budget shortfall of $146 million for the rest of 2025 and a projected gap of more than $1 billion for 2026. Still, alderpeople voiced support for putting more resources into combating the domestic violence epidemic. â€œI think we should be looking not just to maintain those funds but to expand at a time when public safety continues to be top of mind for many Chicagoans,â€ Ald. Matt Martin (47th) said. â€œWe need to make sure weâ€™re doubling down on our investments on services that are working to [address] a growing problem.â€ Support Local News! headline: ICE Detains 2 People Outside NW Side Homeless Shelter, Angering Elected Officials
author:
by
				Molly DeVore
article_text: NORTH PARK â€” Federal immigration agents detained and then released two people Tuesday outside a homeless shelter in Budlong Woods, according to the Illinois Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights. About 7:30 a.m. Tuesday, Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents showed up at the family shelter at 3034 W. Foster Ave., said Andre Gordillo, director of the family support network for the Illinois Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights. Shelter staff did not let the ICE agents in, but two residents were detained outside the shelter. Gordillo said shelter staff confirmed the residents were later released, though he did not know how long they were held or where they were taken. Elected officials and activists held a press conference Wednesday at River Park to denounce the detainment. â€œThis is an immigrant neighborhood, and we are going to protect our people,â€ said Ald. Rossana Rodriguez-Sanchez (33rd). Rodriguez-Sanchez went to the shelter and spoke with the staff Tuesday morning. Volunteers with the Northwest Side Rapid Response Team and the Albany Park Defense Network also patrolled the area Tuesday. Shelter staff said ICE agents were looking for a man who no longer lived at the shelter, Gordillo said. The Northwest Side Rapid Response Team issued a community alert about the activity Tuesday morning. The Budlong Woods shelter was formerly a Marine Corps building. It was bought by the city in 2023 as thousands of asylum seekers were arriving in Chicago. The shelter was originally used to house migrants, many of whom were fleeing political and economic upheaval in Venezuela. It became a family shelter after the city combined the migrant and the homeless shelter systems last year. Ald. Samantha Nugent (39th), whose ward encompasses the shelter, said she wishes the federal government would â€œask us what we need because we need a lot of things.â€ â€œWe would welcome the opportunity to work with the federal government to provide more housing,â€ she said. Gordillo and Doug Schenkelberg, executive director of the Chicago Coalition to End Homelessness, said Tuesday was the first time theyâ€™d heard of an ICE agent detaining someone outside a homeless shelter in Chicago. Schenkelberg said he has not heard about ICE agents targeting any homeless encampments in the city, but â€œitâ€™s something weâ€™ve been worried about.â€ Shelters, schools, churches and hospitals were considered sensitive locations and were protected from immigration enforcement under former President Joe Biden. President Donald Trump ended these protections in January. â€œPeople who have nowhere else to go should have access to shelter and other lifesaving services without fear of detainment,â€ said Arturo Hernandez, an attorney with the Chicago Coalition to End Homelessness. Marcos Charles, acting head of ICEâ€™s Enforcement and Removal Operations,Â recently said about 50-60 percent of the Chicago operation arrests were targeted arrests. That means they were specific people that ICE was trying to find because they had committed a crime, said Ramona Riecke, of the Albany Park Defense Network. â€œIn other words, despite their stated goals, ICE openly admits that they are arresting and detaining people without criminal backgrounds,â€ Riecke said. â€œThey are targeting all members of our communities at all hours of the day and with increasing aggression.â€ Riecke said volunteers will continue to patrol the area for the next few days. She encouraged anyone who sees potential lCE activity to contact the Illinois Coalition for Immigrant and Refugee Rights at 855-435-7693. â€œWe have a vast and wide coalition of people in Albany Park that will stand up and love and defend our neighbors,â€ state Sen. Graciela GuzmÃ¡n said. â€œThey could stand to learn a lesson from Chicago.â€ Support Local News! Subscribe to Block Club Chicago, an independent, 501(c)(3), journalist-run newsroom. headline: Leo High School Choir Nabs 4th Place In â€˜Americaâ€™s Got Talentâ€™
author:
by
				Leigh Giangreco
article_text: CHICAGO â€” The wild ride for the Leo High School choir came to an end Wednesday night as â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talentâ€ host Terry Crews announced the singing group came in fourth place during the showâ€™s season finale. The choir, made up of 18 students from the all-boys Catholic high school on the South Side, performed on Tuesday night as one of 10 finalists. Led by Choir Director LaDonna Hill, the boys sang a lively rendition of The Scriptâ€™s â€œHall of Fame.â€ Dressed in combat boots and preppy cardigans emblazoned with the letter â€œL,â€ the choir came out stomping and clapping to the beat. When orange and white streamers, the schoolâ€™s colors, shot out from the stage, you could see Leo Principal Shaka Rawls beaming in the audience. â€œI am thrilled with all of you,â€ said judge Simon Cowell, known for being the most critical of the four celebrity judges. â€œLook, it doesnâ€™t matter what we say; itâ€™s what is happening behind me. The energy â€¦ I watch people when you perform, and you just have an ability to make people feel great.â€ Judge Howie Mandel pointed straight at the camera and toward the viewers at home, urging them to vote for the choir. â€œYouâ€™re the kings of saying, â€˜Donâ€™t judge a book by its cover.â€™ You hear thereâ€™s a choir coming up next, you have a certain image,â€ Mandel told the group. â€œBut you guys are a vibe. Iâ€™d go to see you; Iâ€™d buy tickets. You need to vote for them.â€ The choir was out front and center once again when the â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talentâ€ results show kicked off Wednesday with a happy birthday song celebrating the 20th season of the series. For their final performance, the boys sang â€œIâ€™m the Manâ€ with Aloe Blacc. When fellow competitor Steve Ray Ladson strapped on his guitar and played his original song, â€œBoots Like Mine,â€ the boys returned to this stage. This time, they donned cowboy hats and boots, joining Ladson in a funky version of line dancing. A post shared by America's Got Talent â€“ AGT (@agt) Even as they achieved national fame during their run to the finals, Blacc encouraged the boys â€” none of whom are trained singers â€” to keep pushing. â€œYouâ€™ve already made it to one of the greatest stages in the world,â€ Blacc told them. â€œDream bigger and never, ever give up.â€ After 45 minutes of performances and recaps, the show finally whittled down the remaining competitors, with the Leo choir vying for the last of five spots against the dance crew, Team Recycled. While Crews waited to announce the winner of the fifth spot, the crowd chanted, â€œLEO, LEO, LEO!â€ When Leo emerged victorious, the boys held their hands over their mouths in disbelief. Hill clasped her hands and turned her eyes up. â€œYou see who didnâ€™t make it through,â€ Cowell said. â€œIt makes you realize how good these acts are.â€ The choir didnâ€™t make it past the next round, however, placing fourth. â€œYou are gonna inspire so many people, and I really mean that,â€ Cowell told the group. â€œIâ€™m so proud of what youâ€™ve achieved. You have an amazing mentor.â€ In an interview with Block Club after the results were announced, Hill expressed a mix of disappointment that the choir didnâ€™t win the overall competition; gratitude for every educator and parent at the school; and pride in her students, who she said had been given the opportunity to â€œgrow exponentiallyâ€ with each round in the show. Hill never expected her choir would end up on a platform like â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talentâ€ or that they would return for several rounds. â€œMany of them Iâ€™ve had for four years. What we built is relational. Beyond music, it was building trust. It was building character,â€ Hill said. â€œSo for God to allow us to have gotten to this plateau is absolutely a blessing and a miracle, and it speaks, I think, to their character, to what Iâ€™ve always seen in them.â€ Hill isnâ€™t sure whatâ€™s next for her. She had decided in the spring that this year would mark her final year with Leo, as she wants to take time to decompress, spend time with family and enjoy her church community. â€œI donâ€™t know if a movie will come out, books. I donâ€™t know how this will work out,â€ she said. The praise Hill received from Cowell already felt like a scene straight out of a movie, she said. The famous judge repeatedly called her his â€œfavorite mentorâ€ throughout the show. â€œFor him to have seen me and said that was like a thank-you from all of the thousands of families and kids â€” hundreds, definitely â€” over the 25 year period of being there at Leo,â€ she said. â€œIt was like a kiss from God.â€ The boys arenâ€™t leaving the competition empty-handed. In an introduction video before their performance Tuesday, one of the boys said he â€œfelt that we were underdogsâ€ and noted the struggle that many kids in Chicago face. headline: CPS Loses Millions In Magnet School Money Amid Dispute With Trump Administration Over Diversity Efforts
author:
by

article_text: This story was originally published byÂ Chalkbeat Chicago, a nonprofit newsroom covering Chicago schools. headline: Vacant Pilsen Lot Could Become Affordable Housing For Seniors Under Developerâ€™s Plan
author:
by
				Francia Garcia Hernandez
categories: Pilsen, Little Village, Back of the Yards
article_text: PILSEN â€” A vacant lot at 16th Street and Wolcott Avenue could be turned into an affordable apartment building with over 100 units for older people. Developer Teo Scorte plans to build a seven-story, 106-unit apartment building for people 55 and older at 1606 S. Wolcott Ave. All apartments would be rented at affordable rates and all units would meet accessibility standards, Rolando Acosta, the developerâ€™s lawyer, said at a community meeting Monday. The building, dubbed Casa Bienestar, would have 94 one-bedroom and 12 two-bedroom units. People 55 and older whose income is at 30, 60 and 80 percent of the area median income could apply. Rents would range from $675 to $1,800, Acosta said. There would be parking for 21 cars and a bike room. The building would have a ground-floor courtyard, commercial spaces aimed to attract social service providers, a community room, a library, a lobby and a gym, Acosta said. A laundry room would be built on every floor, and the top floor would have another community room and a terrace, Acosta said. On the ground floor, the developer plans to add two walls â€” one along South Wolcott Avenue and one along the alley â€” where murals could be painted, Acosta said. It would be Scorteâ€™s first fully affordable housing project for older people. The idea for it came in response to feedback shared by neighbors in community meetings about other projects, Acosta said. â€œWeâ€™ve had enough meetings where the community has been asking for more and more affordable housing. â€¦ Essentially, weâ€™re trying to respond and provide what you asked for,â€ Acosta said. To make way for the development, the lot would need to be rezoned from a light industry use to a neighborhood mixed-use. The lot borders the railroad tracks on the north side, so the developer would have to leave room for the railroad embankment, Acosta said. The lot is also at a higher elevation than the sidewalk, so the developer would need to re-grade the lot. The development team completed environmental testing at the site â€” including a review of the lotâ€™s historical use and testing soil samples â€” and found no environmental hazards, Acosta said Some neighbors at the community meeting asked how Scorte can guarantee the building will be used for senior housing. Acosta said the developer is applying for zoning changes and financial support from the city and state that would restrict the property to housing for people 55 and older. If the zoning change is approved, it would only allow the developer to build affordable housing for older people. If city and state funds were not granted and the developer changed its plans, Scorte would have to seek a new zoning change, Acosta said. Other neighbors said the parking lot is too small, so residents could be forced to park in the neighborhood, making it harder for neighbors to find a spot. The development would be near public transportation and meet local parking requirements for senior housing facilities, Acosta said. The 25th Wardâ€™s zoning advisory board recommended hosting a community meeting due to the projectâ€™s size and because the developer needs a zoning change to move forward, said Lucia Moya Calderon, chief of staff for the Ald. Byron Sigcho- Lopez. The wardâ€™s zoning board will review the feedback submitted by neighbors and the meetingâ€™s notes to issue a recommendation to Sigcho-Lopez, who needs to sign off on the rezoning before it heads to City Council. Members of the board Victoria Romero and Cynthia Nambo told Block Club they would recommend hosting another community meeting about the project for neighbors who might have missed Mondayâ€™s meeting due to fear of immigration raids. Neighbors can share their feedback with the 25th Ward office by calling 773-523-4100, emailing ward25@cityofchicago.org.mail or filling out an online form. headline: The Pop-Up Resale Boutique Closing Bucktown Store Sunday After Latest Burglary
author:
by
				Quinn Myers
article_text: BUCKTOWN â€” A resale boutique known for sourcing hard-to-find vintage clothing, sneakers, streetwear and other collectibles is closing its brick-and-mortar store following a burglary in August. The Pop-Up, 1753 N. Damen Ave., was broken into early Aug. 19. Owner Kevin Woods said burglars took about 400 items â€” about a third of the storeâ€™s inventory. That incident was just the latest burglary Woods and his co-owner and wife Molly have experienced since they launched The Pop-Up in 2019 and opened in Fulton Market in 2020. The couple decided to move their store to Bucktown in 2024 after their West Loop storefront was broken into twice in February 2024. After the burglary this summer, Woods has been grappling with how to move forward with his business, and he ultimately has decided to shift to selling only online and hosting brand activations and other events, he said. The Pop-Up is hosting a final sale Friday-Sunday, after which the store will close for good. On Wednesday, Woods said heâ€™s trying to stay positive and reflect on everything he and his wife have accomplished over the past six years and all the people and brands theyâ€™ve gotten to work with. â€œWhat I would tell other people who are entrepreneurs, or younger entrepreneurs, is: You canâ€™t forget your â€˜why,'â€ Woods said. â€œIf your â€˜whyâ€™ is to have fun and enjoy what you do and work with your friends and build a little space for people to hang out â€” that was my â€˜why,â€™ and I feel like we accomplished that.â€ A post shared by thepopup.comğŸ“ (@thepopupdotcom) Kevin and Molly Woods launched The Pop-Up in 2019 when they started doing one-off events at college campuses and in Chicago. They eventually landed a permanent store at 208 N. Green St. in Fulton Market. But in early 2024, the business was broken into twice, resulting in about $200,000 in losses, Woods told Block Club at the time. Many of The Pop-Upâ€™s products are one-of-a-kind and impossible to replace. The burglaries were an â€œinflection pointâ€ for The Pop-Up, causing the couple to close temporarily and seek out a new location, Woods said. They were also outgrowing the original West Loop storefront, he said. After a short hiatus, The Pop-Up reopened in May 2024 in a Bucktown storefront, which was previously home to RSVP Gallery, a well-known boutique for pop art, streetwear and luxury goods created by local legends Don Crawley and the late Virgil Abloh. â€œIâ€™m humbled â€” to be honest with you â€” to have an opportunity to occupy the space after what was here,â€ Kevin Woods told Block Club in 2024. â€œWeâ€™re thankful for the community for kind of rocking with what we got going on.â€ To stock The Pop-Up and find unique items, Kevin and Molly Woods have traveled numerous times to Japan, and they have even brought staff along to do so. headline: How Jeff Tweedyâ€™s Musical â€˜Familyâ€™ Brought His New Triple Album To Life
author:
by
				Justin Curto
article_text: CHICAGO â€” Besides his band Wilco, Jeff Tweedyâ€™s most important musical collaborators are his family. Tweedyâ€™s been performing with his elder son, Spencer, since 2014, when they released the joint album â€œSukierae.â€ Jeffâ€™s younger son, Sammy, and Spencer played on his 2018 solo album, â€œWarm.â€ During the COVID-19 pandemic, Tweedy took advantage of being at home with his two offspring musicians, performing on Instagram livestreams and recording an album, â€œLove Is the King,â€ together, which came out in 2020. For Tweedyâ€™s new triple album â€œTwilight Overrideâ€ â€” his fifth solo effort and first since â€œLove Is the Kingâ€ â€” he wanted to expand his in-studio sound. So he also turned to the closest people he has next to kin: his touring band. â€œI canâ€™t stress enough how wonderful it is to play music with your family,â€ Tweedy said, calling from a Wilco tour stop in Calgary, Canada. â€œAnd this is kind of an extended family, because Iâ€™ve known everybody since they were kids, pretty much, in this group.â€ Along with Spencer and Sammy, the band includes Liam Kazar, James Elkington, Sima Cunningham and Macie Stewart. Local rock fans may already be familiar with these names: Cunningham and Stewart perform as the experimental-rock band Finom, Kazar and Elkington are accomplished singer-songwriters, and Spencer Tweedy just released his first album with folk-rock band Case Oats. â€œTwilight Overrideâ€ is out Friday. Jeff Tweedy and his band perform Nov. 1 at the Salt Shed, 1357 N. Elston Ave., with Macie Stewart opening solo. That lineup has been backing Tweedy since he returned to the road after the pandemic, but their connections run much deeper, he said. He has known Stewart and Kazar since 2012, when he produced â€œTraphouse Rock,â€ the debut album for their high school band Kids These Days â€” which also included a young Vic Mensa and Nico Segal. Kazar and Elkington started touring with Jeff and Spencer Tweedy in 2014, behind â€œSukierae.â€ Cunningham, who is Kazarâ€™s sister, eventually joined Tweedyâ€™s solo band, and she later brought her bandmate Stewart into the lineup. Collaboration drives the musicians, who frequently appear on each otherâ€™s albums and at their concerts. â€œI grew up with Liam and Macie, and obviously my brother,â€ said Spencer Tweedy, who drummed on the album and played some synthesizers and piano. â€œItâ€™s not just going out and hiring some session players or something. This is truly a group that has a language with each other.â€ Jeff Tweedy started writing the songs on â€œTwilight Overrideâ€ to specifically fit the voices in the band. He was inspired by how the group â€œenhancedâ€ the vocal harmonies of his songs live â€” especially with both male and female singers, unlike in Wilco. â€œIâ€™ve always come home from those tours going, â€˜Wow, I wish it sounded like that on the records,â€™â€ Tweedy said. But the musiciansâ€™ voices were only the first part of the equation. Their instrumental solos and improvisations brought the songs to life, adding an exploratory spirit that recalls Wilcoâ€™s early music. â€œIt felt more like a jam session rather than, â€˜All right, we have to get this take,â€™â€ said Stewart, who played violin, dolceola, synths and piano across the record. â€œ[Jeff]â€™s never like, â€˜No, I donâ€™t like that idea. Stop doing that.â€™â€ Whether heâ€™s performing with Wilco or as a solo artist, Tweedy prioritizes openness. He strived to create â€œan environment of experimentation and acceptanceâ€ during the bandâ€™s recording sessions at his Northwest Side studio, The Loft. â€œI donâ€™t really like dictating,â€ Tweedy said. â€œIâ€™d like to hear what somebody comes up with, because itâ€™s going to be different than what I would come up with, and itâ€™s going to be good. Sometimes itâ€™s not going to be what I end up wanting to use, but I definitely want to hear it before Iâ€™ve inhibited it.â€ That approach paid off when the band was recording the song â€œBlank Baby.â€ Cunningham had been inspired by the bass part that Kazar was playing on the song. So Jeff decided to â€œpull the skeleton out of the songâ€ by stripping it down to the bassline and rebuilding around that. The recording that resulted is meditative and grand, with Kazarâ€™s bass counterbalancing ethereal strings and three-part harmony. The songs on the record frequently take surprising turns, like when the singsongy acoustic strummer â€œOut in the Darkâ€ ends by crashing into a wall of electric guitar shredding. Tweedy wanted those â€œbizarreâ€ moments to help break up the albumâ€™s 30-song runtime, he said. Just as often, though, the band members found themselves being surprised by the music they recorded. Stewart said â€œthere was something different that would happen every timeâ€ they played the winding, six-minute highlight â€œOne Tiny Flower.â€ â€œThe most rewarding thing of all is the experience of hearing those things back, immediately,â€ Spencer Tweedy said. â€œWe would do the songs and then be like, â€˜How did this happen?â€™â€ Tweedy planned the project as a triple album from the beginning, hoping to push back against diminishing attention spans. He intentionally wanted it to be â€œslow and big and openâ€ to reward listeners willing to spend th time with it. In all, Tweedy said the band probably recorded enough songs to fill five albums. He pared that down to the final track list, loosely organizing the songs into discs that represented past, present and future. â€œI kept listening to all of it and trying to get somebody to talk me out of making a triple record, and everybody I would play it for would get that thatâ€™s what it had to be,â€ Tweedy said. A post shared by Jeff Tweedy (@jefftweedy) Thereâ€™s a bigger point to the albumâ€™s abundance, as well. In an essay accompanying â€œTwilight Override,â€ Tweedy wrote about embracing creativity as a counter to the â€œendless buffetâ€ of darkness he sees in the world today. â€œWhen you align yourself with creation, you inherently take a side against destruction,â€ he wrote. To Tweedy, collaborating with his bandmates is another way to put that into practice. â€œIt is a model behavior of the world I would like to see,â€ Tweedy said. â€œSitting in a room together and playing a song and centering yourself in the present, and allowing something to happen that wouldnâ€™t have happened otherwise, to make something that wasnâ€™t there when you woke up that morning. All of that feels like, if you can do that, if you have the privilege to do that, I think you should.â€ â€œTwilight Overloadâ€ drops Friday on dBpm Records. headline: New Ordinance Would Allow Chicago Restaurants To Opt In As â€˜Dog-Friendlyâ€™
author:
by
				Patrick Filbin
article_text: LINCOLN PARK â€” Chicago restaurants could soon have the option to allow dogs indoors under a new ordinance that will be pitched to the City Council this week. Ald. Timmy Knudsen (43rd) is introducing an ordinance that would let restaurant owners choose to allow dogs inside their businesses. Knudsen said the idea is aimed at giving small businesses more flexibility and dog owners more freedom to stop in a coffee shop or restaurant while on a walk with their four-legged friends. The measure, which goes before City Council on Thursday, would overhaul city code that currently bans dogs from retail food establishments, except for service animals. Restaurants that want to participate could register as â€œdog-friendlyâ€ businesses by posting signs at their entrances and following a set of health and safety rules. Under current city law, restaurants canâ€™t allow dogs inside unless the animal is a service dog, and dogs are only allowed on patios if the business in question chooses to allow it. In practice, though, plenty of places bend the rules. Enforcement usually comes only if someone files a complaint, leaving business owners vulnerable to surprise inspections and possible fines. Knudsenâ€™s proposal was partly inspired by Sophie Evanoff, owner of Lincoln Parkâ€™s Vanille Patisserie at 2108 N. Clark St. Evanoff was hit with multiple health inspections after patrons reported dogs inside her shop, and those inspections eat up hours of a business ownerâ€™s time and add stress, Knudsen said. â€œItâ€™s usually several hours on the phone, a lot of preparation goes in and really puts business owners on edge,â€ Knudsen told Block Club. â€œWe all know that a lot of businesses have been turning a blind eye to this for a while, but why isnâ€™t there an option?â€ Knudsen worked with the Chicago Department of Public Health and other small businesses to craft a compromise: Let restaurants opt in, but only if they follow a rule book. Stipulations in the proposed ordinance include only one dog per patron, dogs must be on a leash at all times and canine friends must have proof of their rabies vaccination, among others. Dogs wonâ€™t be allowed near kitchens or food prep areas, canâ€™t be fed inside and cannot come into contact with plates, utensils or surfaces under the proposed measure. Employees of these restaurants, no matter how friendly the four-legged friends are, are not allowed to pet or touch the dogs while working with food, per the ordinance. Businesses that opt in would need to use washable surfaces for tables and floors and report any dog bites to 311. Violations could bring fines ranging from $200 to $1,000 per offense, and repeat violations could trigger license suspension. â€œI do want to stress that the ordinance is only for businesses that really want to sign up for this,â€ Knudsen said. â€œAt an extreme, Iâ€™ve heard people ask, â€˜Youâ€™re going to require that a dog can be sat next to me at Alinea?â€™ Thatâ€™s just not the case. There are certain restaurants that would never consider opting into this. But they donâ€™t have to.â€ Knudsen said he sees the measure as not just helping restaurants but also strengthening neighborhoods. Allowing dog owners to spend more time with their pets at local cafes encourages pet ownership, safer communities and local businesses, he said. â€œFor me, it gives business owners the power to run their business and market their business as they want to,â€ he said. â€œI think thatâ€™s a really powerful thing at a time when businesses are mostly having requirements put on them.â€ The cityâ€™s Department of Business Affairs and Consumer Protection and the Department of Public Health would enforce the rules. If passed, the changes would take effect 90 days after approval. Knudsen said heâ€™s already gotten early support from colleagues and restaurant industry leaders, but heâ€™s open to adjustments if issues come up. â€œIf there is opposition, Iâ€™m someone who wants to make ordinances that work,â€ he said. â€œWe can never make things work for everybody, but if there are unintended consequences, we can make sure theyâ€™re fixed by the process of talking to colleagues, advocacy groups and other groups who might be affected.â€ Support Local News! article_text: CITY HALL â€” A proposal to allow additional dwelling units such as coach houses and basement units to be built citywide appears likely to pass City Council this week after alderpeople added additional restrictions to the legislation. Marty Quinn (13th) and other critics, however, have raised concerns that the increase in density would harm the character of single-family neighborhoods and allow development without city oversight. headline: Broadview ICE Facility Now Fenced Off After Days Of Protests

headline: Private Fences Put Up Around Public Park Irk Near North Neighbors
author:
by
				Mack Liederman
article_text: NEAR NORTH SIDE â€” Michele Dreczynski has fond memories of her son riding bikes through the park by her riverside townhouse â€œcompletely free and untethered.â€ That was before the park â€” with city-mandated public hours â€” was fenced in by her homeowner association. Metal gates at River Village North Townhomes, 1005 N. Kingsbury St., have gone up near West Hobbie and Oak streets, completing the fencing around the small, manicured park along the Near North Side riverwalk. The park must be publicly accessible 6 a.m.-11 p.m. daily as part of an agreement with the city â€” but in February, inspectors with the cityâ€™s Department of Planning â€œfound locked gates and unlawful signageâ€ on the parkâ€™s riverwalk side, where fences have been up for a decade, department spokesman Peter Strazzabosco said in a statement. The association recently added signs on the gates with public hours. The park passed a similar inspection this month, Strazzabosco said. But Dreczynski thinks the fences make the park feel closed off to everyone else in Chicago. She said she didnâ€™t sign up to live in a gated community. â€œItâ€™s all to give the appearance of a private park,â€ Dreczynski said. â€œThereâ€™s an old saying: â€˜Fences make bad neighbors.'â€ Next to the gates with the public park signs are new intercom systems with dial pads and an after-hours access code for residents. A larger sign on a stake prominently reads â€œNo Trespassing.â€ An executive at First Community Management, representing the homeownersâ€™ association, said it had no comment. But association President John Courtney pitched residents on the six-figure fences as a safety precaution, according to a letter from last year reviewed by Block Club. â€œThe need for enhanced security became especially urgent in May 2021, following theChicago riots, when crime and burglary spiked in the area, including break-ins or attempted break-ins in some of our units, as well as a significant increase in package theft,â€ Courtney wrote. â€œWeâ€™ve also had productive discussions among neighbors regarding the pros and cons of installing gates.â€ There were no riots in Chicago in May of 2021, so it is unclear what Courtney is referring to. Courtney wrote the fences could raise property values for River Village residents with 24-hour park access and provide â€œincreased privacy.â€ Some of the townhomes have doors with small yards leading directly into the park. He estimated the fences would cost $160,000. That would run homeowners $1,200-$3,000 each, which they could repay monthly over nine years with interest. The fences had to be approved by at least 51 percent of homeowners, Courtney wrote. â€œSome residents were concerned about restricted access for non-residents to enjoy the park,â€ Courtney wrote of the cons. â€œWeâ€™ve addressed this by agreeing to keep the park open during Chicago Park hours.â€ The new fences on West Hobbie and Oak streets enclose the park, which had gates on its riverwalk and North Crosby street sides installed by the homeowner association about a decade ago, said Eric Gierzynski, a longtime River Village resident and former board member of the homeowner association. It wasnâ€™t until June that Gierzynski noticed the gates regularly open during public park hours, he said. The tour boat captain takes his Australian cattle dog, Juniper, for daily walks in the park. â€œBy putting up the gates, everyone will think itâ€™s sealed off,â€ Gierzynski said. â€œItâ€™s been a slow encroachment. â€¦ This is the latest round of this.â€ Caroline Sachay, who lives in a neighboring building and has long enjoyed the park with her poodle, Lakota, called the new fences â€œa bummer,â€ â€œsuper uglyâ€ and â€œa waste of money.â€ â€œIt reminds me of Trump building his wall,â€ Sachay said. â€œItâ€™s another reminder of people giving into their fears.â€ Neighbor Kathi Toll joked that the park is both â€œoasisâ€ and â€œprisonâ€ as she took Brioche, her Pomeranian, for a stroll. â€œTheyâ€™re very formidable,â€ Toll said of the fences. â€œI donâ€™t think we have the type of foot traffic that warrants something like that.â€ Barbara Lancaster said her cockapoo, River, has made friends on their walks around the park. So has she. â€œThe people who own dogs know they can come here,â€ Lancaster said. â€œBut for so many years, they let people think it was private. Why trust them not to do that now?â€ Other dog walkers milling around the sleepy park on a recent Monday said they didnâ€™t want to get involved in the neighborhood kerfuffle. Dreczynski said the decade-long debate over fences has â€œdivided the community.â€ Courtney wrote in the June 2024 letter the project had been â€œunder discussion for some time.â€ â€œAs crime rates fluctuate, as is expected in a large city, and with some residents moving to the suburbs, opinions on the gate project will continue to change,â€ Courtney said. But Gierzynski said he made up his mind a long time ago. â€œIâ€™ll give the board members dirty looks,â€ Gierzynski said. â€œThe world is better when spaces benefit everybody.â€ Dreczynski moved in when the townhomes were built in the early 2000s. Back then, the area was largely part of the Cabrini-Green public housing high-rises, which were all demolished by 2011. â€œThe people who moved here had much more of a pioneer spirit,â€ Dreczynski said. â€œAs buildings were torn down and people were displaced from the [Chicago Housing Authority], there was zero understanding of what people were moving into. Over time, Iâ€™ve seen gates locked and spaces become privatized.â€ River Village is considered a Planned Development, a zoning category dating back to 1988. It was designed to open up the North Branch of the Chicago River to residential and mixed-use developments, transforming it from a declining industrial hub. Planned Developments must be â€œcompatible with the character of existing neighborhoodsâ€ and â€œencourage the protection and conservation of the cityâ€™s natural resources,â€ according to the city. The documents spell out pages upon pages of public benefits, like the requirement River Village keep its park open during typical city park hours. Dreczynski considers herself a watchful eye. â€œTake the casino development; what if they say, â€˜Nobody can now go on its part of the riverwalkâ€™?â€ Dreczynski said. â€œThere must be integrity to the rules that garner a [Planned Development]. These arenâ€™t small changes.â€ Her son is off to college. Now she walks the park with a beagle, Milo. â€œMy goal is to make sure every park sign stays up on every gate,â€ Dreczynski said. â€œItâ€™s still too hard to open the darn gates.â€ Support Local News! headline: â€˜Cooley Highâ€™ Marks 50 Years As Coming-Of-Age Classic Uplifting Chicagoâ€™s Black Communities
author:
by
				Atavia Reed
article_text: ENGLEWOODÂ  â€” When â€œCooley Highâ€ was released in 1975, the scrappy cast and crew had no idea they were creating a coming-of-age classic. The film follows best friends and protagonists Leroy â€œPreachâ€ Jackson (Glynn Turman) and Richard â€œCochiseâ€ Morris (Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs) who live in housing projects on Chicagoâ€™s Near North Side. Over the course of a few days in 1964, they and their pals tease gorillas at Lincoln Park Zoo, play basketball on North Clybourn Avenue, visit a diner at the corner of Elm and Larrabee streets and take part in a few brawls and police chases. Before the weekend is over, the fate of the two friends will be irrevocably altered. Fifty years after its release, the Chicago International Film Festival will commemorate the anniversary with a free screening 6:30 p.m. Wednesday at Kennedy-King College Theater, 740 W. 63rd St. Although online RSVPs for the event are currently full, a representative at CIFF told Block Club that some standby tickets may be available that evening. If you havenâ€™t RSVP-ed yet, he suggested getting to the venue before the doors open at 6:30 p.m. for the best chance at standby tickets. Directed by Michael Schultz and written by former Cabrini-Green resident Eric Monte, â€œCooley Highâ€ is a time capsule that captures what life was once like in the now-gentrified Cabrini-Green neighborhood. The Motown-filled soundtrack â€” featuring â€œBaby Loveâ€ by the Supremes and â€œI Canâ€™t Help Myselfâ€ by the Four Tops, among other hits â€” helps transport the viewer to the days of 1964 Chicago, when the film is set. Today, Cooley Vocational High School is a community of gated apartments. Overgrown vines and weeds now sprout where the protagonists once lived and played. â€œI hope that people will realize the importance that this film has for not only telling a story, but for documenting history,â€ said Pemon Rami, a writer and director as well as former director of educational and public programs at The DuSable Black History Museum and Education Center in Washington Park. â€œWhen you look at â€˜Cooley Highâ€™ and they get on that bus and they ride through that community that is now the Apple Store and Crate & Barrel, history is documented in the visuals of those films in that era.â€ Rami worked with Schultz to do preliminary location research for the film and help cast its star parts, he said. â€œCooley Highâ€ was responsible for jumpstarting the careers of local powerhouses like Jackie Taylor, founder of the Black Ensemble Theater in Uptown. Movies like John Singletonâ€™s 1991 debut â€œBoyz N the Hoodâ€ likely wouldnâ€™t exist without â€œCooley Highâ€ to pave the way. Wednesdayâ€™s event will feature a panel discussion with Rami, Taylor, Grow Greater Englewoodâ€™s Anton Seals Jr. and WGN producer Tyra Martin immediately following the screening. â€œI think the film was so popular and is so popular because it shows the strong side of what it means to be Black in Chicago,â€ Taylor said. â€œThe film showed the opposite of what was perpetuated [about] Cabrini-Green. The film showed the truth. We were a family. We had ups and downs like any other family, but we cared about each other. We supported each other and we helped each other.â€ A post shared by Michael Dembov (@chicago_history) â€œCooley Highâ€ is an autobiographical story based on Monteâ€™s life ditching school, making friends and â€œdoing some crazy thingsâ€ while growing up in the Cabrini-Green projects, he said in a 2006 interview with the Philadelphia Inquirer. When people talked about crime and violence in America at the time, Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn and Cabrini-Green in Chicago were always at the center, Monte said. But he had â€œone of the best childhoods imaginable,â€ with best friends and the greatest mother, he said. He wrote â€œCooley Highâ€ to depict that side of life, he said. Monte quit his job as co-creator of the Black-family sitcom â€œGood Timesâ€Â  to focus on â€œCooley Highâ€ because he â€œknew it was going to be a hit,â€ he said. The film earned $13 million at the box office on a $750,000 budget. â€œWhen we were developing movies during that period of time, the purpose was to uplift the people that were watching it and to uplift our communities to make them feel better about themselves,â€ Rami said. â€œThe nature of â€˜Cooley Highâ€™ to me has more to do with the ability to show what friendship was like, what male relationships were like, and also what the times were like.Â It was the first opportunity that we had to see our people in that light.â€ Making â€œCooley Highâ€ feel real extended beyond the page. Rami, an artist with connections across the city, cast aspiring actors from the local theater scene â€” many whoâ€™d never starred in a movie before, he said. When scouting locations, Rami met with members of the street gangs in Cabrini-Green to inform them about the movie, he said.Â Some of the cast were real members of a local gang in Chicago. â€œThat was part of my responsibility, going in and doing locations to get people to know that we had their best interests at heart,â€ Rami said. Taylor was one of the filmâ€™s breakout stars. She plays Johnny Mae, one of Cochiseâ€™s love interests. Taylor, who grew up in the Cabrini-Green neighborhood, could recognize some of the characters Monte was referencing in the film, she said. The experience of acting in a film so close to home â€œtouched my heart,â€ she said. â€œ[Cabrini-Green] was simple,â€ Taylor said. â€œWe were young kids, doing what young kids do, and we all had ambitions.â€ The film is just as important now as it was when it was released, she said. â€œâ€˜[Cooley High]â€™ focuses on humanity,â€ Taylor said. â€œIt doesnâ€™t focus on the violence of humanity, except to say violence is ignorant and it should not be tolerated by anyone. It resonates because people can relate to it and the emotions from it are human emotions.â€ Like the similarly themed 1973 coming-of-age film â€œAmerican Graffiti,â€ â€œCooley Highâ€ ends with epilogue-like updates on the charactersâ€™ lives. One is inspired to go to Hollywood and become a successful screenwriter to commemorate his friends. At its core, that success is what makes â€œCooley Highâ€ stand the test of time, Rami said. The movie is real in its portrayal of Black communities, but thereâ€™s still a â€œwinâ€ that brings us back to the film, he said. â€œSomebody has to win at the thing, to not only be able to tell the story, but also to be able to reflect all our future possibilities,â€ Rami said. â€œI hope that, as people look back at this film, they realize the importance of storytelling is identifying who youâ€™re writing for, why youâ€™re writing the story and what you want people to do once they see it.â€ Support Local News! headline: 56-Story Residential Tower Pitched For Mag Mile
author:
by
				Melody Mercado
article_text: DOWNTOWN â€” A newly proposed 56-story apartment tower would bring nearly 500 apartments to the Magnificent Mile. AMLI Residential, a luxury apartment developer, is proposing a 498-unit apartment tower at 669 N. Michigan Ave., currently home to the Niketown store, Ald. Brendan Reilly (42nd) announced in his weekly newsletter. The proposed 668-foot tower would feature retail space on its first and second floors, parking on levels three through seven, amenity space on levels nine and 41 and apartments on levels 10-40 and 42-55, according to a presentation for the development. Of the 498 apartments, 337 would be â€œefficiencyâ€ or studio units and 161 â€œstandardâ€ apartments with one or more bedrooms, according to the presentation. The plans also include 199 parking spaces and a 200-space bike storage room. Fifty residences, about 10 percent of the total units, would be designated as affordable. Such developments are required by the city to set aside 20 percent of units as affordable, but Amli plans to make an in-lieu payment to the Chicago Housing Authority to satisfy its remaining affordability requirement, according to a presentation outlining the plans. Plans show the building would stand on the northeast corner of Michigan Avenue and Erie Street and extend north towards Huron Street. The parking entrance would be along Erie Street, while trash and loading zones would be on the alley behind the building, parallel to Michigan Avenue. A traffic study by Kimley-Horn & Associates, Inc., found that traffic in the area is expected to stay about the same if the proposal is approved as-is. The study found that during the busiest hours, wait times at nearby intersections are projected to rise by no more than five seconds, with lines of cars growing by about three cars. The main trouble spot could be the westbound lanes of Ontario Street at Michigan Avenue, where evening rush-hour backups may get about three cars longer and sometimes stretch into the next intersection. The problem comes from traffic lights that arenâ€™t in sync: Michigan Avenueâ€™s light stays green longer than nearby St. Clair Streetâ€™s, so westbound drivers on Ontario often sit through a couple of St. Clair cycles before they can cross Michigan. Reilly said in his newsletter the development would help bring more foot traffic and customers to the Magnificent Mile, which has struggled with vacancy issues post-pandemic but has recently seen a rebound with new retail tenants, including the Harry Potter Shop. â€œThis project represents continued private investment along the Magnificent Mile and supports efforts to keep Michigan Avenue an active and attractive corridor for residents, businesses, and visitors,â€ Reilly wrote. The project needs approval from the Chicago Plan Commission and City Council before construction can begin. Residents can submit feedback to Reilly on the proposal here. Support Local News! headline: Does Chicago Comfort Food Exist For Vegans? Yes â€” And We Found It
author:
by
				Linze Rice
article_text: CHICAGO â€” Chicago is a meat town. Tell someone you donâ€™t like all-beef hot dogs or your Italian beef dipped in gravy and you may get an obscene hand gesture. During its Union Stockyard years, the city used â€œeverything about the hog except the squeal,â€ Upton Sinclair wrote in his 1906 novel, â€œThe Jungle.â€ At the 1893 Worldâ€™s Columbian Exposition in Chicago, Vienna Beef was just getting its start, charging a dime for sausages covered in mustard and onions from a booth in the â€œOld Viennaâ€ exhibit. The food spot became so popular, the brothers-in-law behind it decided to stay in town, building a legacy that became integral to Chicagoâ€™s identity. Yet at the same Worldâ€™s Fair, the Vegetarian Federal Union also set up an exhibit as a competing movement was taking shape: going meatless. Some advocated against using animal products altogether. As Chicago in the late 1800s was turning to those very animal products to bulk up its big shoulders, it was simultaneously becoming the â€œepicenter for vegetarianism,â€ according to historians. Today, Chicago is home to Vienna Beefâ€™s Hot Dog University as well as The Vegan Museum. PETA recently recognized our meat-loversâ€™ town as the epicenter of vegan-friendly cuisine. In a city that still consumes meat and cheese like air and water, Block Club wondered: Are comfort food staples like Italian beef and deep-dish pizza as readily available to vegans as they are carnivores? As it turns out, yes. Hereâ€™s where to find vegan versions of some of Chicagoâ€™s most loved and consumed foods. A post shared by Kitchen 17 â€“ 100% Vegan Restaurant (@kitchen17chicago) Do Chicagoans eat deep-dish pizza every day? Of course not. Should they be able to if they want? Absolutely â€” and that includes vegans. Cue Kitchen 17, 2554 W. Diversey Ave. in West Lakeview, where you can get 12- and 16-inch deep-dish pizza, sans animal products, with toppings that include meatless pepperoni and sausage and housemade vegan cheese. Online reviewers say itâ€™s one of the best vegan deep-dish pies in the city.Â Pizzas start at $24 and go up from there, depending on size and toppings. Warehouse Bar & Pizzeria, 1419 W. Fullerton Ave. in Lincoln Park, offers 10- and 14-inch vegan deep-dish pizzas filled with Selfish Cow vegan cheese. Pizzas start at $23.95, with the option to add meat-free sausage or pepperoni. For the casual pizza consumer, Warehouse also offers a vegan thin-crust option. And no Chicago pizza discourse would be complete without mention of the pizza puff. Canâ€™t Believe Itâ€™s Not Meat, 1368 1/2 E. 53rd St. in Hyde Park, serves up a vegan version with meatless â€œItalian meat,â€ vegan cheese and spinach, with fries and mild sauce. Hot dogs are practically a way of life in Chicago. Fortunately, this rite of passage is available to all local eaters, carnivores or not. Among the options: You can also get a Chicago-style vegan dog at institutions like The Wieners Circle in Lincoln Park, Budackiâ€™s Drive In in Ravenswood, Portilloâ€™s and Rate Field. Need even more options? Here are 22 other veggie dogs Chicagoans love. A post shared by Canâ€™t Believe Itâ€™s ğŸš« Meat (@cantbelieveitsnotmeatinc) Hot links â€” spicy little sausages smothered in barbecue sauce â€” are a staple on the South and West sides. Get four vegan hot links â€” drenched in housemade sauce and served with seasoned fries and wheat bread â€” from Canâ€™t Believe Itâ€™s Not Meat in Hyde Park, 1368 1/2 E. 53rd St. Every city has a signature meat sandwich. Chicagoâ€™s is the Italian beef. You can get a regular one just about anywhere in the city, but for a vegan-friendly version, go to Canâ€™t Believe Itâ€™s Not Meat in Hyde Park, 1368 1/2 E. 53rd St. For $15.95, the Italian Not Beef serves up thinly sliced vegan beef with sweet peppers and housemade au jus on a French roll; itâ€™s topped with mild giardiniera and served with a side of seasoned fries. Top it off with vegan cheese for 75 cents, and if youâ€™re feeling extra Chicago, add a vegan Italian sausage for $5. Google reviewers give the sandwich a â€œ10/10â€ and claim they â€œcouldnâ€™t believe it wasnâ€™t meat.â€ You can also grab a plant-based beef at Buona, 613 N. McClurg Court in Streeterville. Buonaâ€™s Italian Beefless Sandwich ($8.99) uses Uptonâ€™s Naturals seitan made exclusively for the restaurant chain, plus vegan cheese and roasted sweet peppers. Originating in Chicagoâ€™s Puerto Rican community, the jibarito is a sandwich that swaps fried plantain patties for slices of bread and is stuffed with veggies, cheeses, sauces and meat. The Jibarito Stop, 1646 W. 18th St. in the Heart of Chicago neighborhood, had been a go-to spot for vegan jibaritos, but the restaurant remains temporarily closed after a debilitating fire earlier this year. Itâ€™s unclear when it will be able to reopen. Fortunately, Chicagoans have other options â€” notably, Smash Jibarito, a popular pop-up restaurant thatâ€™s had a kitchen residency at Desert Hawk, 2049 W. Division St. in West Town and recently opened its first permanent location on Humboldt Parkâ€™s Paseo Boricua. Known for its unique take on a jibarito-meets-smashburger, Smash Jibarito offers a vegan version of its Ogillo and Estilo Animal sandwiches, replacing the beef patties with an Impossible burger patty and removing the cheese and mayo. headline: Lakefront Synagogue In Edgewater Wants To Build A New Home â€” And Possibly Add Housing
author:
by
				Madison Savedra
article_text: EDGEWATER â€” Emanuel Congregation, a synagogue in Edgewater, is planning a redevelopment of its longtime home, hoping to embrace its lakefront views â€” and potentially bring in a commercial or residential component. Emanuel Congregation, 5959 N. Sheridan Road, opened in Edgewater in 1955 after buying the land in 1944, according to synagogue leaders. At the time of construction, officials were considering having DuSable Lake Shore Drive continue north past its current end point of Hollywood Avenue and into the north suburbs, which wouldâ€™ve partitioned the synagogue from Lake Michigan. As a result, the synagogue was designed with the assumption that there would be a highway in its backyard; the entire east side of the building is soundproofed and doesnâ€™t have any windows â€” or views of Lake Michigan, said Andrew Degenholtz, a member of Emanuel Congregationâ€™s executive committee. But only a few years after the synagogue opened, officials decided against extending the drive to the suburbs and ended the highway at Hollywood Avenue. The synagogue was also built to hold a lot more capacity than what it currently needs; at its peak, the congregation had about 1,000 households, and it currently has about 250 households, Degenholtz said. The number of households has slightly increased over the past couple of years, but the existing 35,000-square-foot building is still too large, too inefficient and too expensive to maintain, Degenholtz said. Recently, the synagogueâ€™s leaders have been planning how they could improve its current home and ensure its future for generations to come, Degenholtz said. They decided to finally move forward with initial steps to build a new home, announcing the plans to their membership earlier this year. Renderings of what a new synagogue could look like show a building that sits closer to the lakefront with a circle driveway on the west side. It would have windows all around, including in the sanctuary, where religious services are held. Being able to bring that element of being close to nature and the lake will be a boon to the synagogueâ€™s community, said Emanuel Congregation Cantor Shelly Friedman. Right now, the best views of the lake can be found in the synagogueâ€™s parking lots, which abuts the building on the east side, she said. The synagogue also neighbors residential high rises along Sheridan Road, another development that was not there when the campus was built. Congregation leaders are considering adding a residential or commercial element to the campus, but there are no concrete plans for that element at this time, they said. The synagogue plans to have robust community engagement to determine what neighbors would like to see added on the site, leaders said. The priority is to build a long-lasting home for Emanuel Congregation, but if thereâ€™s a way to bring in the greater Edgewater community into their plans, theyâ€™d like to, Friedman said. â€œWe love that weâ€™re a Jewish community, but weâ€™re a Jewish community at our best when we open up our doors to everybody,â€ she said. One hurdle the synagogue redevelopment will need to face is its zoning. The building predates Chicagoâ€™s modern zoning code and isnâ€™t in conformity with its current zoning designation, which means itâ€™ll need to be changed before any redevelopment could happen, synagogue leaders said. It will also need to go through additional city regulations due to its proximity to Lake Michigan, as it falls under the Lakefront Protection Ordinance. Support Local News! headline: Lawmakers Block $4 Million In Grants From Partially Closed Weiss Hospital, Demand Repairs
author:
by
				Manny Ramos
article_text: UPTOWN â€” State lawmakers said they are blocking $4 million in grant aid from being sent to the closed Weiss Hospital after its owner â€œghostedâ€ the community. The move comes a month after Manoj Prasad, owner and CEO of Weissâ€™ parent company, Resilience Healthcare, promised he was working with lawmakers to file an appeal with the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services.Â State Sen. Mike Simmons said he canâ€™t get Prasad to return a phone call as the deadline to file the appeal approaches despite his and other lawmakersâ€™ successful efforts to funnel more money into Weiss. â€œDr. Prasad ghosted us,â€ Simmons said. â€œWe need the CEO of this hospital and his private equity billionaire buddies to get their act together because weâ€™ve done our part.â€ The lawmakers joined about two dozen community organizers Monday outside of the hospitalâ€™s closed emergency room at 4646 N. Marine Drive to call on Prasad to file an appeal and fix the litany of problems facing the hospital. The deadline to file an appeal with the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services is Wednesday. But the appeal is only one step toward getting the hospital up and running again. Hospital leadership will need to address the many problems that prompted the feds to kick Weiss out of the Medicare program,Â which accounted for more than 65 percent of inpatient revenues in 2024, according to the most recent data collected by the state. â€œThe sudden closure of Weiss weeks ago â€¦ was truly shocking and devastating to our community,â€ said Lilly Le, organizing director for the Vietnamese Association of Illinois. â€œSince the closure, we know hundreds of staff have lost their jobs. We know medical residents who had to terminate their leases to move outside of Chicago and some of whom have impacted visa status because of the termination.â€ Le said there is a strain on nearby hospitals that were forced to absorb the patients who would normally be treated at Weiss. â€œAmidst the federal cuts and attacks on community support systems, we are here to make it very clear: Owner Prasad closed Weissâ€™ doors and ceased most of its operations due to his own mismanagement and neglect,â€ Le said. â€œHis lack of communication and efforts show us that he does not have the communityâ€™s interest at heart.â€ Prasad pushed back against the claims levied against him in a written statement in which he accused others of not appreciating his efforts to turn around the hospital. He said if it wasnâ€™t for him buying the hospital in 2022, the previous owners wouldâ€™ve shut it down long ago. â€œWhere was everyone in December 2022, when the hospital was scheduled to permanently shut down? Why did no one come forward to help then or even later?â€ Prasad said in the statement. â€œIs the communityâ€™s expectation that I would come to your community to save a bankrupt hospital from closing and from losing hundreds of jobs and also bring a boatload of money while everyone else simply looks on or will they ever step up and help get the desperately needed funds?â€ Community members have worked to save the hospital for over a decade and have raised concern over Weissâ€™ rotating cast of private-equity-backed owners. They even rang the alarm to state regulators over Prasadâ€™s efforts to buy the hospital. Ald. Angela Clay (46th) was one of those organizers calling on state regulators to look closer at the sale of the hospital and whether Prasadâ€™s team could deliver on his promise to keep the hospital open. â€œWe told you that this would happen. This is the first time that Iâ€™ve ever said, â€˜We told you soâ€™ and didnâ€™t want to tell you something,â€ Clay said. â€œWhy donâ€™t we listen to the community? Why donâ€™t we listen to the people who are going to be impacted?â€ Clay said buying Weiss was just a ploy to shut down the hospital and take over its prime real estate, which is a stoneâ€™s throw from the lakefront. â€œIt is also a reality of what happens when you have private equity firms coming to prey on poor people,â€ Clay said. â€œHow can we have an institution that swears that it is for the people and by the people, come in and close its doors on the same people it swore to protect?â€ Prasad did not respond to questions about whether he will file the appeal by Wednesday but said he has been in discussions with â€œseveral highly regarded law firmsâ€ and â€œplans to timely file the appeal.â€ â€œWe have been in discussions with the state, county and city leadership and have obtained support for our efforts,â€ Prasad said. â€œOne must remember, Weiss is a small safety-net hospital that has suffered many years of abuse and neglect that will need to be addressed. Safety-net grants need to be more evenly and equitably distributed so Weiss may get its fair share.â€ Yet, lawmakers like state Rep. Hoan Huynh said thatâ€™s not entirely true. He said he and others fought to get Weiss the â€œsafety-netâ€ designation with the state, which allowed the hospital to qualify for millions of dollars in grants. â€œWe were able to bring back millions and millions of dollars to this hospital every year from Springfield,â€ Huynh said. â€œIt was up to them to make sure they were able to make the proper adjustments to fix their existing problems [and] existing infrastructure violations.â€ Huynh said he and others arenâ€™t confident Prasad is going to spend the money appropriately, which is why they are withholding the money until an appeal is filed. The state has responded to repeated violations happening at Weiss and has produced nearly a dozen investigative reports since January, according to records obtained from the Illinois Department of Public Health. In June, Weissâ€™ air conditioner went out and left patients seeking care in sweltering heat. The hospital was forced to shut down its emergency department and transfer most patients to its sister hospital, West Suburban Medical Center in Oak Park. That hospitalâ€™s air conditioning also went out, leaving patients in sweltering conditions again. In July, state investigators again surveyed Weiss Hospital and found that patients in the emergency department werenâ€™t getting proper care because of â€œlack of equipment and monitoring devices.â€ During that visit, two doctors told investigators the hospital was unsafe for patients. One doctor said the emergency department continues to â€œnot be safe due to lack of ability to monitor and treat appropriately.â€ The other doctor said they had â€œserious concernsâ€ about the care patients were receiving and that the emergency department wasnâ€™t able to â€œsafely intubate a patient.â€ The group that huddled outside of Weiss Monday attempted to hand deliver a petition to Prasad that called on him to keep the hospital open. headline: Comedian Cameron Esposito Returns To Chicago With â€˜FEAT,â€™ A Show About  Feet And Parenting
author:
by
				Ariel Parrella-Aureli
article_text: CHICAGO â€” Itâ€™s been 15 years since comic Cameron Esposito has lived in Logan Square â€” and yet, every time they visit the city, it feels frozen in time for them. The nationally recognized comic, actor and writer from suburban Western Springs spent their formative years in Chicago, teaching and performing while living at Troy and Diversey. Milwaukee Ave., in 2009, and it has become an award-winning comedy open mic thatâ€™s drawn everyone from up-and-coming comics to well-known names. At the time, it was a new concept that gave space to comics of different backgrounds, especially women and queer people like Esposito, they said. â€œIt kind of gave permission to some folks who wouldnâ€™t usually be at a mic to not just be on the list, but also come perform,â€ Esposito said during a recent interview with Block Club while visiting family in Lincoln Park. â€œWhen thereâ€™s different perspectives on a lineup, it makes everything better.â€ Esposito, 43, now lives in Los Angeles, but their Chicago memories have influenced how they perform and see the world, they said. Next month, theyâ€™re returning to Chicago for their Steppenwolf debut with â€œFEAT,â€ a comedic solo showÂ based on a near-death experience last year that forced them to take a closer look at parental relationships, childhood and parenting styles â€” which theyâ€™ll perform while being â€œvery pregnant,â€ Esposito said. Although Esposito didnâ€™t time the show with their pregnancy, the symbolism of performing with a large belly while discussing parents and childhood may be the universeâ€™s own doing, they said. â€œYou donâ€™t know how the timing is going to work, but the universe is like, â€˜I gotchu,'â€ Esposito said. â€œI canâ€™t believe how much the universe wanted me to do this at Steppenwolf.â€ When it was time to find a venue, Steppenwolf was the first that came to mind, and they knew the debut had to be in Chicago. Coming back to perform a painfully honest and impactful show like â€œFEATâ€ at a renowned theatrical institution is a dream come true for Esposito. â€œFEATâ€ is about a foot surgery infection that turned into a full-body illness that almost killed Esposito. During the traumatic time, they wore diapers and were taken care of by their mother, who flew out to Los Angeles to live with them. â€œI was so sick, I was literally in diapers,â€ they said. â€œI donâ€™t think many people in their 40s get to see what their mom would be like when they were like a teeny kid, and especially leading into having a child, it was like an incredible mindfâ€” â€” when you are in diapers, you can see how somebody might parent.â€ That pivotal time led to the showâ€™s creation, complete with a pun for a title, which was an easy task since Esposito has always used real-life experiences to create their one-person comedy shows that use humor and have a story arc. â€œIt just feels like it was unavoidable for me, and that kind of the work Iâ€™ve always done, and that started here in Chicago,â€ they said. Esposito hopes the show will attract a diverse audience ranging from parents to teens who are beginning to understand adulthood and see how parenting styles change over time, they said. Esposito doesnâ€™t miss a beat when they talk about how the city and its open mics shaped them as a comic. Because there isnâ€™t as much of an official comic industry and all eyes arenâ€™t on Chicago, artists have time to develop and â€œeat sâ€”, which everybody does at the startâ€ before refining their skills and finding their space, Esposito said. â€œBecause people do different jobs here, itâ€™s like a real audience, and L.A. doesnâ€™t really have that,â€ they said. Since leaving Chicago, Esposito has released four comedy specials and albums; has appeared on Netflix, Max, ABC, NBC and Hulu; hosted two long-running, popular podcasts â€” â€œPut Your Hands Togetherâ€ and â€œQueeryâ€ â€” and released a best-selling memoir, â€œSave Yourself.â€ And yet, one of their proudest moments in life and as a comic is creating the open mic night at Coleâ€™s Bar, they said. â€œI grew up in a community where everybody knows each other, even in the city, so I think that was always my goal, to create community,â€ Esposito said. â€œThat lasting legacy â€” again, itâ€™s so cheesy. Not every standup comic is like, â€˜I hope I can create community in my wake everywhere I go,â€™ but itâ€™s just my personality. I canâ€™t escape my personality.â€ FEAT runs Oct. 3-4 at Steppenwolf. headline: Obama Center Housing Ordinance Set For Final City Council Vote
author:
by
				Maxwell Evans
article_text: SOUTH SHORE â€” A drastically modified slate of South Side housing protections passed City Councilâ€™s housing committee the same day it was introduced afterÂ the initial proposal  stalled in theÂ committee for nearly two years. The South Shore Housing Preservation Ordinance â€” a sweeping proposal to fund homeownership programs and reserve city-owned land for income-based housing â€” was introduced by Ald. Desmon Yancy (5th) in October 2023. The ordinance had been stuck in the councilâ€™s housing committee since its introduction, while fellow South Shore Alds. Greg Mitchell (7th) and Michelle Harris (8th) did not publicly support its passage. Yancy, along with Alds. William Hall (6th) and Jeanette Taylor (20th), introduced a substitute Jackson Park Housing Pilot Ordinance during Wednesdayâ€™s housing committee meeting. Backers made â€œsignificantâ€ changes to the original proposal, Yancy said. The new proposal reflects its predecessorâ€™s broad goals around increasing affordable housing stock and accessibility near the future Obama Presidential Center, though many details were changed. Committee members passed the substitute ordinance Wednesday. The proposal could receiveÂ a final council vote as soon as Thursday. The Jackson Park ordinance proposal would reserve vacant, city-owned lots at 63rd Street and Blackstone Avenue, 69th Street and Stony Island Avenue, 67th Street and Dorchester Avenue, 71st Street and Paxton Avenue and 1708 E. 71st St. for affordable apartments. At least 75 percent of the units in these developments would be affordable to residents making up to 60 percent of the area median income, or $71,940 for a four-person household. The ordinance would also: The proposed ordinance now focuses on a â€œpilot areaâ€ bounded by 60th Street, King Drive, South Chicago Avenue, 71st Street and DuSable Lake Shore Drive â€” which includes nearly all of Woodlawn and parts of South Shore and Greater Grand Crossing. The original proposal would have covered all of South Shore. â€œWeâ€™ve worked really, really hard to bring the other South Shore alders on board, and were unfortunately just not able to get there,â€ though provisions like the tax relief program would still benefit the whole neighborhood, Yancy told Block Club Tuesday. Mitchell â€” whom Yancy accused of assaulting him during an argument over the proposal last year â€” and Harris did not respond to requests for comment. After the original proposal stagnated for more than a year, efforts to retool it picked up this summer with support from Mayor Brandon Johnsonâ€™s office, Yancy said. â€œI donâ€™t think we wouldâ€™ve gotten here without the support of the mayorâ€™s office,â€ he said. Spokespeople for Johnson did not respond to requests for comment. The ordinanceâ€™s passage would be â€œa win for the Jackson Park community,â€ Yancy said. â€œIt sets a floor that we can build on as we look at increasing the area that could be supported by this sort of work.â€ The new proposal would create an Office of the Tenant Advocate that would educate tenants about their rights, as well as city housing policies and laws. The office could also contract with other agencies to offer services like emergency relocation assistance. The ordinance would also provide legal services to renters facing eviction who make less than 80 percent of the area median income, and it would give tenant associations in the pilot area a chance to buy their properties before they land on the open market. Some aspects of the original South Shore proposal â€” like caps on rental application fees and security deposits, bans on move-in fees and neighborhood-specific modifications to the 2021 affordable requirements ordinance â€” were cut from the updated version. The Jackson Park proposal is â€œmore cognizant of the current budget of the city of Chicago, which is why [itâ€™s] mostly budget-neutral,â€ Yancy said. The modified proposal also reflects concerns over the Trump administrationâ€™s push to slash federal housing funds and dismantle equitable housing programs, he said. â€œWe made sure [the ordinance] couldnâ€™t be explicitly tied to race, even though itâ€™s on the South and West sides,â€ Yancy said. â€œIt had to be something that would stand up to challenges in court, and I believe this meets a pretty high bar.â€ The latest proposal would be another â€œhugeâ€ step toward limiting displacement near the Obama Center if it passes, said Dixon Romeo, executive director of Southside Together and a member of the Obama CBA Coalition. The coalition helped draft and rally support for the initial and modified proposals. Though the bulk of the latest proposal doesnâ€™t reach south of 71st Street, South Shore residents have made clear their desire to â€œcover the whole neighborhoodâ€ with housing protections, and work to secure legislation in the neighborhood, will continue, Romeo said. â€œWhat this ordinance does is it shows that we can build on the work that we were doing before,â€ Romeo said. â€œWe built off the Woodlawn ordinance to get here, and we can build off this one to get our final version. â€œAny time you can say thereâ€™s gonna be, at minimum, thousands of people who â€” not tomorrow, but soon â€” are going to get more housing â€¦ thereâ€™s no way I could look at that and say this [latest proposal] is a compromise or a sacrifice. Weâ€™re moving the ball forward.â€ Voters in four South Shore precinctsÂ overwhelmingly supported protectionsÂ like those outlined in the ordinance in a non-binding ballot question in November. Similar questions about housing protections were on some South Side votersâ€™ ballotsÂ in 2019Â andÂ in 2023, garnering support from nearly 90 percent of voters in each election. Some South Shore residents and real estate professionals spoke out against the new proposal during Wednesdayâ€™s meeting, saying they only learned of the legislation days ago and calling on alderpeople to hold off on a vote so it could be modified. â€œThe fact that we were only given updates on this ordinance yesterday â€¦ means that thereâ€™s something woefully wrong with the way the system is working,â€ said Sharon Lewis, a South Shore resident and founder of the Meadows Eastside Community Resource Organization.â€ The proposalâ€™s use of vacant land along 71st Street and Stony Island clashes with plans in progress for the commercial corridorsâ€™ development, said LaShawn Brown, program manager for Special Service Area No. 42. The agency and the South Shore ChamberÂ are developing the CorridorLive plan, which lays out a framework for resident-led and -owned business developments along 71st Street. â€œSouth Shore has so much to gain and so much to lose,â€ Brown said. â€œThis ordinance, without â€¦ allowing community members to see it and discuss it and amend it, risks undermining the catalytic investments already underway. â€œA balanced approach â€” protecting affordability on side streets while fostering mixed-income, market driven growth on corridors â€” is the only way to ensure 71st Street and Stony Island becomes the thriving community asset it was always meant to be.â€ Some opponents to the Jackson Park ordinance said at Wednesdayâ€™s meeting they were not against affordable housing and supported some form of a community benefits ordinance, which Yancy pledged to support during his 2023 aldermanic campaign. However, South Shore homeowners have often opposed affordable apartments andÂ policies which prioritize low-income residents, citing the existing concentration of renters with housing choice vouchers in the neighborhood afterÂ public housing was eradicated elsewhere. A 2017 Roosevelt University studyÂ found South Shore was home to 3,528 renters with vouchers. At the time, that was more than the combined population of voucher holders in 30 other community areas, including nearby Hyde Park and East Side. Advocates have called for an increase in affordable housing in all neighborhoods, amid local and national housing crises. Homelessness in Chicago increased by 207 percent from 2023 to 2024, and by 116 percent in Illinois, according to the Illinois Office to Prevent and End Homelessness. That was driven in part by â€œdrasticallyâ€ increased housing costs, assistant director Colleen Mahoney saidÂ earlier this year. Support Local News! article_text: CHATHAM â€” A wellness center specializing in mental health support and servicing the cityâ€™s most vulnerable communities is open and accepting new clients on the South Side. William Hall (6th), whose ward includes the wellness center, opened his ward office in the same building in 2024. Access to mental health care has often been â€œoverlooked and underrepresentedâ€ in communities like Chatham, said Trilogy CEO Susan Doig. Trilogy has provided services on the South Side for 15 years, but with the completion of the wellness center, the nonprofit is promising a â€œpermanent investmentâ€ and commitment to the South Side for years to come, Doig said. â€œWeâ€™re not only here to celebrate a grand opening but to reaffirm our commitment to a healthier tomorrow, one in which all people have access to behavioral health services no matter what ZIP code you live in,â€ Doig said. September is Suicide Prevention Awareness Month and Recovery Month â€” two topics that are essential to the work Trilogy does every day, Doig said. â€œWe are providing life-saving services,â€ Doig said.
