He rides his bike from the West Side to the Chatham building each day to meet with people and spread love, he said. â€œIâ€™m very honored to be here in a mentally healthy state of mind,â€ Fields said. â€œThat doesnâ€™t mean that Iâ€™m healed. headline: Riot Fest Closes With â€˜Riot Fest Dayâ€™ Mayoral Proclamation, Green Day And Chicago-Area Bands
author:
by

article_text: NORTH LAWNDALE â€” Chicagoâ€™s leading punk festival wrapped its 20th edition Sunday with Green Day bringing out thousands of fans; a lineup packed with Chicago-area bands, including The Effigies, Smoking Popes, Screeching Weasels, Pegboy, Dehd and Footballhead; and a surprise appearance by Mayor Brandon Johnson. To honor the anniversary, the fest also debuted the Riot Fest Historical Society museum, housed in a building modeled after Logan Squareâ€™s Fireside Bowl. Standouts over the weekend included â€œWeird Alâ€ Yankovic playing to a ginormous crowd, a jubilant set by British band James that resulted in an on-stage dance party for their biggest hit â€œLaid,â€ the gleeful fake-blood-soaked performance rock of GWAR â€” and Stamos finally making his Riot Fest debut, performing with the Beach Boys. On Sunday, The Effigies and Footballhead showcased different generations of Chicago alt-rock. The Effigies, a punk band prominent in the â€™80s, performed their debut album, â€œFor Ever Grounded,â€ which turned 40 last year. Two stages over, alternative rock group Footballhead made their Riot Fest debut, thanking their hometown for the opportunity. â€œIt would be nothing without the support of our community,â€ said singer Ryan Nolen. â€œWeâ€™ve been playing in Chicago DIY bands for 10 years, and this opportunity is never guaranteed, so to get to play this today is incredible.â€ â€œWe love Chicago. â€¦ This festival has always been so fun to attend, and playing it too is a world-class experience,â€ Nolen said. Northwest suburban pop punk band Smoking Popes celebrated the 30-year anniversary of their sophomore album, â€œBorn To Quit,â€ featuring their biggest hit, â€œNeed You Around,â€ and punk band Pegboy played a full album performance of their debut â€œStrong Reaction,â€ garnering a strong reaction from the crowd. The set quickly progressed to crowd surfing, with lead singer Larry Damore entering the crowd. Midway through the day, the mayor made a surprise address to the media, proclaiming Sunday as Riot Fest Day. Riot Fest is â€œa part of the legacy in the history of Chicago. The way you bring people together from all different backgrounds, this is who we are as a city,â€ Johnson told Riot Fest founder Mike Petryshyn during the public proclamation. â€œMike, you are Chicago.â€ â€œFor the first time, I feel like Iâ€™m accepted in Chicago,â€ Petryshyn said tearfully. Johnson made the announcement inside the Riot Fest Historical Society on the festival grounds, a facsimile of Fireside Bowl, a prominent punk music venue in the â€™90s and 2000s. Johnson toured the building with Petryshyn, looking at memorabilia and merchandise from past festivals and photos honoring the festivalâ€™s investments in the North Lawndale community. Later in the day, other local groups, including Screeching Weasel and Dehd, took to the stage. Screeching Weasel, a Prospect Heights-based band, performed their 1991 album, â€œMy Brain Hurts,â€ as the crowd steadily grew ahead of headliner Green Day. article_text: DOUGLASS PARK â€” It was all about John Stamos on day two of Riot Fest Saturday, as the â€œFull Houseâ€ star made his triumphant debut at the festival after years of online ribbing from its organizers. Festival organizers had acquiesced to a list of Stamosâ€™ nine demands before he would appear at the fest this year, including: organizer â€œRiot Mikeâ€ Petryshyn getting a tattoo in his honor, the creation of a Chicago Greek-style pizza and a John Stamos lookalike contest, which drew hoards of fans on Saturday afternoon around the famed Stamos butter statue. Among 15 competitors, Wicker Park resident Chris Maimonis was crowned the winner. He told Block Club it felt â€œlike a dream come true.â€ â€œPeople have been telling me I look like Stamos since I was a little kid, and then as soon as they made this contest, everybody I know started texting me, telling me I gotta get in it,â€ he said. â€œI literally bought the ticket today just because of this.â€ While Maimonis had never been to Riot Fest before, he was looking forward to the rest of the day, especially seeing Jack Whiteâ€™s set. â€œItâ€™s gonna be fun walking around today, Iâ€™ll tell you that,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m just on top of the world right now.â€ Based on cheers, the seeming runner-up was Lincoln Park resident Griffin Snead. â€œIâ€™m gonna call myself that, thatâ€™s for sure,â€ Snead said of being runner-up. Donning a black jeans, a green button up shirt and oversized leather jacket, Snead said he dressed the part, channeling the style of Uncle Jesse, Stamosâ€™ â€œFull Houseâ€ character. He found out about the contest through X, formerly Twitter, and radio announcements, he said. Though Sneadâ€™s been to Riot Fest three times so far, he showed up Saturday specifically for the contest. â€œIt was a blast. It was a great way to meet a bunch of people with incredible hair,â€ he said. â€œThatâ€™s what its really all about, is celebrating incredible hair and Greek heritage.â€ And finally, after a 12-year pursuit involving online harassment, Stamos himself appeared at the alternative rock fest. At 6:20 p.m. Saturday, despite light rainfall and storm threats, Stamos took to the Riot Stage alongside The Beach Boys. He stepped out playing guitar and donning an on-brand black leather jacket and shades. â€œHow about it, after all these years, John Stamos is here?â€ singer Mike Love asked the crowd. Stamos first played with The Beach Boys about 40 years ago, and one of his first big shows was a 4th of July concert at the Washington Monument in 1985, according to the Ravinia Backstage Blog. Stamos said the first song he sang with the band was â€œBarbara Ann,â€ per the blog â€” which they played Saturday night. Other favorites performed by The Beach Boys included â€œForever,â€ which was featured in â€œFull House.â€ Clips of the classic sitcom played in the background as they performed. Eventually, Stamos took off his leather jacket to reveal a special Riot Fest T-shirt, and also swapped out his guitar for the drums. He praised the fest for â€œribbing me all these years.â€ â€œYouâ€™ve kept me humble,â€ he said. GWAR, known for their intense constumaery and over-the-top theatrics, also attracted a ginormous crowd Saturday afternoon on the Rebel Stage, splattering them with fake blood, which could be spied on attendees long after their set. And it was really good.â€ Seeing their growth is â€œcrazy,â€ Hackett said. â€œIt was amazing, and the mosh pit really set the vibe for the whole thing,â€ said Hackett, who lives in Logan Square. â€œWe didnâ€™t know any of the people who started that mosh pit so it wasnâ€™t family, but they all seemed to really be enjoying it. It was really fun, and they had a good turnout.â€ Knuckle Puck, a five-piece rock band that formed in the suburbs in 2010, were on the Rise Stage at 5:20 p.m. They played a 60-minute set to a big crowd and celebrated 10 years since the release of their album, â€œCopacetic.â€ At 7:25 p.m., flocks of festgoers gathered at the Roots Stage for Jack White, guitarist and lead singer of defunct rock duo the White Stripes. headline: â€˜Weird Al,â€™ Rilo Kiley And Alkaline Trio Kick Off Riot Festâ€™s 20th Year
author:
by
				Gwen Ihnat
article_text: DOUGLASS PARK â€” For most people, going to Riot Fest every September is an adventure all by itself. But for its 20th anniversary this year, Riot took things a step further, offering several destinations within the fest in a â€œChoose Your Own Adventureâ€-type format. Attendees flocked to Fridayâ€™s Riot Fest kickoff, usually the calmest day, and what turned out to be the only mudless one this year as rain hit the area late Friday. Some Riot Fest attendees who had purchased tickets from Costco didnâ€™t realize that they had only purchased vouchers that needed to be redeemed hours before the fest to have the digital tickets show up on their phones. The confusion led to some fans approaching the Riot Fest box office for help, but tickets were eventually delivered within 45 minutes. Those who are heading to the fest with Costco tickets Saturday or Sunday should redeem them before heading out so they arrive in time. Once inside, attendees filed past the familiar carnival rides and games right after the entrance. But as they ventured deeper into Douglass Park, alternative experiences awaited. Like â€œRiotoberfest,â€ a spot-on recreation of a German Fest-themed bar, complete with Riot Fest Ale and sausage sandwiches. Next to â€œRiotoberfestâ€ is a recreation of a karaoke bar for brave wannabe vocalists. As with previous years, Riot also offered a â€œClerksâ€-themed convenience store offering ice cream, water, sunglasses and toiletries from deodorant to condoms, as well as a wedding chapel. Riotland also featured a recreation of the Logan Arcade and a Fireside Bowl recreation featuring the â€œRiot Fest Historical Societyâ€ with posters and merch highlights from the past 20 years. Naturally, that all revolved around the famous John Stamos butter statue, as fans anxiously await his possible appearance Saturday drumming with the Beach Boys. But those fun experiences aside, the crowd was there to see the music, with the typical diverse Riot Fest lineup featuring bands from around the world (as well as locals) in as many genres as you can imagine. In anticipation of â€œWeird Alâ€ Yankovicâ€™s closing set, the Rise stage was renamed for him for the day as â€œWeird Alâ€ Yankovicâ€™s Weird World Stage. That stage kicked off at noon with Japanese pop-punk trio Shonen Knife. The Rebel Stage soon followed up with locals The Tossers, offering an inspired mix of Irish jig and punk ethos. Back in the land of Weird, Puddles Pity Party drew an extremely large crowd anxious to see a Pagliacci-like whiteface clown singing covers of popular music (and it must be said that Puddlesâ€™ alter-ego Mike Geier has some pipes.) After a few standards like â€œIâ€™m Always Chasing Rainbows,â€ Puddles brought out a disturbing Ronald McDonald-like fellow clown from the band Mac Sabbath to play guitar on skewed covers of Ozzy Osbourneâ€™s â€œCrazy Trainâ€ and Celen Dionâ€™s â€œMy Heart Will Go On,â€ dosed with a little Metallica. Locals Harmâ€™s Way brought the Riot Fest mosh pit back in earnest as enthusiastic fans thrashed to the bandâ€™s particularly fierce brand of hardcore (ear plugs strongly recommended). For a little less fierce and a lot more tech, iconic outfit Sparks played to a riveted crowd led by singer Russell Maelâ€™s strong-as-ever animated vocals and his brother Ron Maelâ€™s keyboards, in front of a full backing band. Russell Mael kicked off the set by asking the crowd â€œSo May We Start,â€ referring to the bandâ€™s song of the same name, and the crowd roared in agreement. Sparks then unfurled other hits like â€œThis Town Ainâ€™t Big Enough for Both of Usâ€ and â€œThe Number One Song in Heaven.â€ Over on the Rebel Stage, Mattoonâ€™s own Didjits returned for their first show in 20 years. Lead singer Rick Sims is the only member left from the original lineup, but the master frontman did his typical wowing of the crowd, offering cryptic one-line intros to songs like â€œ(Mama Had a) Skull Babyâ€ and â€œUnder the Christmas Fish.â€ Sims also did his typical mocking of the crowd, making fun of the fact that the punk band was playing a â€œfestival.â€ As the day stretched into evening, Brooklyn-based indie rockers The Hold Steady wowed fans with an album play performance of â€œSeparation Sundayâ€ in front of a rapt crowd. Rilo Kiley, an indie band that hadnâ€™t played Chicago since 2008, packed the Radical stage, where frontwoman Jenny Lewis delighted fans with her incredible vocals, intoxicating stage presence and songs that many fans hadnâ€™t had a chance to hear in many years. Lewis has had a robust solo career, and visits the city often, but watching her rock out alongside singer and guitarist Blake Sennett, drummer Jason Boesel and bassist Pierre â€œDukeâ€ de Reeder took many in the audience back to their college days, leading to crowdwide singalongs to â€œWith Arms Outstretchedâ€ and â€œPortions for Foxes.â€ Local punk rock outfit Alkaline Trio also had an album play performance of 2000â€™s â€œMaybe Iâ€™ll Catch Fireâ€ in front an enthused crowd of diehard fans of the trio that dates back to the â€™90s heyday of Chicago punk rock. They kicked off with familiar hits like â€œPrivate Eyeâ€ and â€œCalling All Skeletonsâ€ before diving into the album, performing some cuts that hadnâ€™t been seen on stage since 2015. But ultimately, it was â€œWeird Alâ€â€˜s day, and the pop-culture icon did not disappoint with this stop on his â€œBigger and Weirder 2025â€ world tour. He offered a video plethora of his appearances in TV shows and movies from â€œNaked Gunâ€ to â€œThe Simpsons.â€ This montages gave him the opportunity to make multiple costume changes, donning a fat suit for â€œFat,â€ scooting around on a hoverboard for â€œWhite & Nerdyâ€ and impersonating Kurt Cobain for â€œSmells Like Nirvana.â€ The worldâ€™s most famous accordionist has so many songs that he had to offer many via medley format, although some, like â€œAmish Paradise,â€ got the full treatment, complete with backing choir. The huge crowd roared its approval, one of the biggest to ever pack the Rise stage area, making navigation through the crowd extremely difficult.
